title: Brooks vs. Bryson: The Feud Energizing the U.S. Open
sub_head: The hostility between Brooks Koepka and Bryson DeChambeau has invigorated golf fans. This is what it sounded like at Torrey Pines.
body:
SAN DIEGO—Bryson DeChambeau has a habit of muttering to himself. “Two days in a row I’ve missed it far left,” he said to no one in particular after bogeying the par-3 third hole Friday. “That’s unbelievable.”
This same quirk is also what has invigorated the feud that’s dominating golf and attracting more crowd attention than anything else at this U.S. Open. It’s Brooks vs. Bryson.
It hasn’t been a secret that Bryson DeChambeau and Brooks Koepka don’t particularly like one another, and that was before a leaked video last month showed Koepka cursing about DeChambeau at the PGA Championship. And the tension between the pair—two of the best golfers in the world—has only escalated since.
Both are now in the hunt entering the weekend here at Torrey Pines. Both are at even par through two rounds, placing them five strokes behind the co-leaders Richard Bland and Russell Henley. Both are more than capable of erasing a deficit of that size in just 18 holes.
DeChambeau is the reigning U.S. Open champion. Koepka is a four-time major winner. And the crowded galleries following the two in their respective groups reflected the drama that has gripped the sport.
